The training rule on one-month robes, the third training rule on one-month robes. At that time the Blessed One was at Jetavana AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada-ÄrÄma in ÅšrÄvastÄ«. There are two kinds of robes:
The first is a new robe, that is, a new robe.

If one is old, sick, or powerless, or if the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« respectfully serves the venerable ones and is happy to wash for them, and if she is a disciple, all of this is without offense.

Soiling means making them wash and dye, even if it is just dipped in dye once. Beating means beating or patting with the hand just once. If it is not a relative, and one thinks it is not a relative or is unsure, and makes them wash, dye, or beat, one commits a pÄrÄjika offense.
If it is a relative, but one thinks it is not a relative or is unsure, and makes them wash, dye, or beat, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

If one intends to wash this robe but mistakenly washes another robe, one only commits an offense of wrong conduct, not a pÄrÄjika offense requiring relinquishment.
If one sees one's disciples acting improperly and does not stop them, because of improper instruction, the teacher also commits an offense.

As for saying there is no offense, it means either the robes and belongings of the Three Jewels, or having a nun relative do it, or sometimes washing it oneself, or having one's teacher wash it, or having an upÄsaka or upÄsikÄ, or having a nun relative do it but not a non-relative, all of which are without offense.
There are four kinds of having others wash robes:
First, not washing;
Second, slightly washing;
Third, washing well;
Fourth, over-washing.
Like this, dyeing and beating also have four distinctions. The offenses have light and heavy according to the circumstances.
There are five kinds of natural dyes, namely root, bark, leaf, flower, and fruit.
However, there are two kinds of colors that are not proper:
First, the eight kinds of major colors.
What are they?
The verse says:
Purple mineral, madder, turmeric, vermilion, azurite, and red lac,
Yellow ochre and lac resin are the eight major colors. Bhiká¹£us should not use them to dye robes.
Second, deep red color and light red color.
If one attaches to these two kinds of colors with a mind of enjoyment, they are all impure and one incurs the offense of wrong doing.
If there is a patron who, with a mind of respect and reverence, brings large colored robes to offer, a bhiká¹£u should use other colors to spoil the large color. When wearing it, there is no offense.
When wearing clothes, one should abandon three kinds of minds and give rise to five kinds of minds.
The three kinds are:
First, the mind of delighting in adornment;
Second, the mind of using with contempt;
Third, the mind of deceitfully seeking fame, later pretending to wear coarse clothes, wanting others to know of one's virtue and practice, hoping to attract profit and praise.

One should not give rise to these three kinds of minds, but only seek to spoil the color and obtain enough to cover the body, in accordance with the teachings of the Great Teacher, and progress in cultivating wholesome dharmas.
The five kinds of minds are: First, knowing the proper amount;
Second, knowing the intervals;
Third, knowing contemplation;
Fourth, knowing the time;
Fifth, knowing the number.

As for knowing the proper amount, when using robes, know the amount of the new and old and use them accordingly, slowly and gently, not letting them be damaged or lost, as they are difficult to obtain later.
As for knowing the intervals, one cannot always wear the same robe frequently, as it will become smelly and quickly worn out, so it should be used in intervals.

As for contemplation, the mind always contemplates that the source of this robe is extremely difficult, not from one's own strength, but from the generosity of others. With a mind of repaying kindness, when using it, do not do anything illegal.

As for knowing the time, use it in accordance with the proper amount according to the weather, whether cold or hot. If it is out of season, it will harm oneself and others. Harming oneself means not benefiting one's own body, and harming others means merit will not increase.
As for knowing the number, with the thirteen requisites one can fully support the body. Keeping too many in storage and seeking more will increase greed and waste one's work.
The summary verse says:
Knowing the proper amount, knowing the intervals, contemplating, recognizing the time,
Knowing the number, using the robe, benefiting oneself and others.
If the robe needs washing, one may wash it oneself, or have one's disciples, male or female lay followers, or a trustworthy washer do it, but one should not be careless and damage the robe.
There are five benefits to washing robes:
It removes foul odors, prevents lice and nits, prevents itching, allows the robe to take dye, and makes it last longer.
Not washing the robe results in the opposite five faults.
There are also five benefits to wearing dyed robes:
It conforms to the appearance of sages, prevents arrogance, does not attract dust and dirt, prevents lice and nits, and makes the robe soft to the touch and easy to care for.
There are five faults to over-washing robes:
It causes them to wear out quickly, makes them unfit for hard use, makes caring for them a mental burden, creates unnecessary trouble, and obstructs wholesome activities.
There are also five faults to wearing a well-dyed robe:

Because it causes arrogance and indulgence to arise in oneself and jealousy in others, because it causes others to know that one is fond of grooming and good looks, because it can cause much toil and hardship when seeking, because it can obstruct wholesome activities, and because the excess dye damages the durability of the garment.
If one beats it excessively, there are also five faults, four of which are the same as before, and the fifth is that excessive beating damages the durability of the garment.
Because the bhiká¹£u Nanda beat his robe excessively, the Buddha said:
One who uses robes should not beat them or beat them excessively.
If one obtains a robe that is well beaten by a donor, with good color and softness, one should use it.

Some explain that based on this, beating is generally prohibited.

Therefore, it is known that it prohibits excessive beating, but does not prohibit beating.
Moreover, it sends to wash, dye, and beat, prohibiting non-related nuns, but does not obstruct others. It is known that the robe has the meaning of being allowed to be beaten, as explained above.
Those who do not follow this will all incur the offense of confessing an offense face-to-face.
